Screening for Retinopathy / 13010 / 3.0
Page  of
Purpose
Identify infants who are at risk of developing Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP).
Ensure that infants in at risk categories are referred to the Ophthalmology team for screening at the appropriate time.
Timely treatment for ROP is effective at preventing severe vision impairment.
To ensure that the correct referral pathway is followed for accessing clinic appointments for infants following discharge.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix D)
Screening Criteria
All babies born at less than 32 weeks gestation (up to 31weeks and 6 days) or with a birth weight less than 1501grammes at birth should be referred for screening for ROP.
Screening Protocol
Babies born before  weeks gestation (up to 26 weeks + 6 days) – the first ROP screening examination should be undertaken at 30 to  weeks correct gestational age.
Babies born between  – 32 weeks gestational age (up to 31 wks + 6 days) – the first ROP examination should be undertaken between 4-5 weeks (28 to 35 days) postnatal age.
Babies >32 weeks gestational age but with birth weight <1501g the first ROP screening examination should be undertaken between 4-5 weeks (28 to 35 days) postnatal age.
Minimum frequencies of screening should be weekly when:
The vessels end in zone I or posterior zone II; or
There is any plus or pre-plus disease; or
There is any stage 3 disease in any zone.
Minimum frequencies of screening should be every 2 weeks:
Until the criteria for termination have been reached.
All babies < 32 weeks gestational age or birthweight < 1501g should have their first ROP screening examination prior to discharge.

Where a decision is made not to screen a baby, the reasons for doing so should be clearly stated in the baby's medical record and the examination should be rescheduled within one week of the intended examination.
Procedure for Referral
Within the first 7 days of life all babies that meet the ROP criteria, should have a referral form (refer to Appendix A) completed and emailed to the Opthalmology Consultant Secretaries.
At the same time the babies' names should be entered in the ROP diary on the Neonatal unit for the date that their first examination is due.
Names and dates should be communicated to the ROP link nurse for their records.

As part of the referral process parents should be informed of the reason ROP screening is undertaken and receive the parent information leaflet “Screening for Retinopathy of Prematurity” (refer to Appendix C). Parents should be encouraged to ask any questions they may have.
Eye Drops
An hour before the examination is due the first eye drops should be given as follows:
Tropicamide 0.5% 1 drop each eye;
Phenylephrine 2.5% 1 drop each eye.
These drops should be prescribed and signed for on the drug chart under the ROP screening section
These should be repeated after 5 minutes.

Proxymetacaine Hydrochloride 0.5% are anaesthetic drops for pain relief during the examination and should be prescribed and signed for on the drug chart under the ROP section. These should be available on the unit for use at the examination if required.
Clinic Follow-up and Termination of Screening
Babies will be followed up in the ophthalmology clinic following their discharge from the Neonatal unit at the discretion of the Ophthalmology team.
Screening can be stopped when a baby is no longer at risk of sight threatening ROP.

Babies who have never had ROP have minimal risk of developing sight threatening ROP when vascularisation has extended into Zone III and eye examinations may be stopped when this happens usually after 36 weeks gestation.

Babies who develop ROP which does not meet criteria for treatment screening can be safely stopped when there are clear signs that the active progression of ROP has halted and regression has commenced. This must be demonstrated on two successive examinations.
Documentation
Referrals to the Ophthalmology department are made using the specific Retinopathy screening form which will then be filed in the patients' medical notes by the ROP link nurse.
The examination is documented on the yellow examination record form (Appendix
B) by the clinician performing the screen. This is added to the medical notes and subsequent examinations added to it.

ROP examinations must be recorded on the National Neonatal Care Record System (BadgerNet) using the Ad Hoc forms for that day and the daily update sheet. The examinations must be included in the discharge letter with any arranged follow-ups.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after undertaking any patient contact.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust 04071 Standard infection prevention policy.
Staff and Training
All medical and nursing staff will have training in the referral pathway for infants at risk of ROP.
All medical and nursing staff will undertake training on how to correctly record ROP screening on SEND as part of their training in the use of SEND and this will be recorded as part of the appraisal
Staff must be aware of the correct prescription of eye drops required prior to examination.
Teaching sessions on the identification of the ‘at risk' infant will be available to all medical and nursing staff, facilitated where necessary during the monthly staff meetings on the Unit.
Audit and Monitoring
As part of the National audit the figures for compliance for ROP screening will be collected from the BadgerNet Database.

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly notifications are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.

Guideline monitors have been nominated to each clinical area to ensure a system whereby obsolete guidelines are archived and newly approved guidelines are now downloaded from the intranet and filed appropriately in the guideline folders. ‘Spot checks' are performed on all clinical guidelines quarterly.
Where a baby's notes have demonstrated that the appropriate action has not been taken a Datix should be completed. This will address any further training needs for staff that requires updating.

During the investigative process of reviewing the Datix, numerous sets of notes will be requested and analysed in relation to compliance with the guidelines and identify where there is either non-compliance and/or where the guidance does not support the evidence based practice. This can be demonstrated in the Risk Management data trend analysis. Furthermore this process can also identify areas of good practice.
Communication
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Focus Magazine that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.
Staff are encouraged to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders.
References
Guidelines for the screening and treatment of Retinopathy of Prematurity (May 2008), Royal College of Paediatrics & Child Health, Royal college of Ophthalmologists.
